awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Collaborative Research: Tools for Mental Health Reflection: Integrating Social Media with Human-Centered Machine Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
The widespread adoption of wearable devices and social media is generating population-scale data about people's behavior as situated in their everyday lives.  Prior research has shown how machine learning techniques can use such data in modeling attributes of individuals' health and wellbeing; these techniques are also promising additions to tools that support self monitoring practices and health interventions outside of clinical contexts.  However, most such tools enable only simple mechanisms to review one's data, and require high compliance from individuals actively volunteering relevant information. These limitations prevent such tools from effectively supporting reflection, that is, conscious re-examination of prior experiences to form new understanding. Reflection is a key to improved health and health maintenance, and recent work has shown the promise of data-driven health reflection. Effectively supporting reflection, however, requires more sophistication than simply showing a patient their data. This project will develop tools to support reflection for eating disorders (ED) by combining voluntarily shared and unobtrusively gathered social media data with strategic presentation of machine learning analyses. The interface designs will meet the needs of multiple stakeholders: patients, family members, and clinical partners.  By doing so, the research will result in novel mechanisms to support the treatment of ED, going beyond existing personal health informatics tools by being sensitive to the complex psychological struggles of ED patients.

The proposed research will follow a multi-phase process, interleaving the use of machine learning and human-centered approaches. The first phase will seek to understand the current practices of three stakeholders, patients, clinicians, and support network members, involved in ED reflection. In the second phase, informed by those current practices, we will develop theoretically-motivated, and psychometrically and clinically validated, machine learning techniques to support ED inference and reflection based on analysis of both textual and visual social media data. The third phase will use participatory design methods to develop interactive tools that encapsulate these machine learning techniques in order to support ED reflection among the three stakeholders. This final phase will include evaluating these tools through a field deployment to understand how they become embedded in and affect current practices of ED reflection.  These activities will lead to complementary contributions in the areas of machine learning and of designing for reflection, offering novel approaches to outstanding challenges surrounding mental health and facilitating novel collaborations between computational and clinical researchers. Broader implications of the research will include conducting mental health outreach activities in the researchers' respective campuses and facilitating the training of the next generation of cyber-human researchers and professionals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Eating disorders (ED) constitute a significant health issue, affecting 28.8 million Americans (https://staging.nationaleatingdisorders.org/statistics/). Many of these individuals document their experiences on social media (often anonymously). This project explored how machine learning (ML) could be applied to those social media data to support ED patients, not only to understand their condition but also to aid in their recovery.


The first phase of our project involved interviews both with eating disorder patients and with clinicians. We found that participants regularly emphasized the importance of reflection in ED recovery. that is, participants (both clinicians and patients) described the value of being able to look back on past experiences, as well as to understand and to appreciate how far one has come. They also emphasized that recovery is not a goal to be achieved but a lifelong journey.


Based on these findings, the second phase of our work explored ML techniques to analyze changes over time in social media data about ED. Our findings from the second phase highlighted a number of common patterns. In one example, posts about triggers for relapse were often followed by a gap in posting, which was then followed by posts about connecting with one’s social support network. An awareness of such patterns may help individuals have a better sense not only for where they are in their own ED recovery, but also where their journey may take them next.


The third phase then explored how to design an interactive system to support ED patients in reflecting on that journey. In reviewing the space of existing ED apps, we found that most focused on quantitative recording of behaviors and feelings: calories consumed, number of meals per day, emotional states, etc. However, relatively few existing apps supported higher-order considerations, such as helping patients challenge holistically how they think and feel about their condition. To complement this review of existing apps, we also recruited participants from a variety of online ED-focused sites and communities. We then asked these participants to complete a variety of participatory design exercises to help explore the space of potential systems that could support higher-order reflection on one’s ED recovery journey.


The fourth phase drew on results from the second and third phases to design and to implement an interactive prototype system. This system shows patterns and trends identified in social media posts about ED experiences, such as the pattern above where posts about triggers are followed by a gap in posting, which is then followed by connecting with one’s support network. The prototype highlights how, at any given point in the recovery journey, different paths forward are possible. For instance, some social media users in the above pattern would follow the gap in posting with content about healthy recipes, while still others might report on therapy sessions. We then conducted an evaluation of this prototype with some of the same individuals who participated in the work conducted for phase 3. During these evaluations, the participants spent relatively little attention to changes over time. Instead, they focused more on finding posts and/or users they identified with. While this process did not emphasize the recovery journey in the manner intended (that is, as something that unfolds dynamically over time), participants did reflect on the similarities and differences between themselves and other ED patients.


Finally, synthesizing across these studies, we have released a publicly available website: https://socweb.cc.gatech.edu/ed_stories/. This site draws findings from across the studies conducted for this work to provide guidance for ED patients in understanding their own condition. In addition to highlights from our research, the site also directs visitors to resources that can support ED recovery. In this way, the findings of this project can reach beyond academic publications and work toward addressing the broader societal health issue of eating disorders.
